text: Patient: Right. Doctor: Huh, so we’d have to check with your insurance. Do they cover clinical trials, if you’re interested? Patient: Okay. Doctor: Huh, if they are. Then in the forms that we give them and give you, it tells them, huh, what they’re paying for, and it tells you what we’re going to pay for. So definitely the dummy vitamin C or the real vitamin C we pay for because that’s experimental. Your insurance company may have to pay for the time in the chair to get the medicine. Okay? Huh, if you have to pay five dollars every time you come into this building, huh, this study could cost you more money because you’re here more often. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Huh, but if you don’t have a copay for visits, then that’s, you know. So there are some hidden costs. You know? If you’re coming in more often and you have to pay for parking and, you know, those sorts of things, huh, we do have the ability for some of our studies to pay for your parking. We do. Or even if you need a ride here, there’s a group of, do you live in the city? Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Yeah. We definitely have a program to help city residents if they have trouble getting in that often. Huh, huh, you know, the chemotherapy is going to cause hair loss. Huh, seventy-five percent of the time you lose your hair, it grows back. Huh, you might get excess tearing because it can block the tear ducts. So a little bit. The other reason why we might want to wait a little bit is just to see how much your palsy is going to get better. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Huh, huh, it drops blood counts. So right now your white count’s good. Your platelets are good. Huh, but we may need to give you a blood transfusion if we make you more anemic. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Huh, huh, we can drop your blood count, white count, and so you might get a higher risk of infection. Huh, usually we know about that. We tell you to be careful. Sometimes we give you antibiotics. And if it happens every time, sometimes we’re going to give you a medicine that’s going to bring up your white count so it doesn’t drop. Patient: Okay.

text: Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: A mitosis means however the cell’s dividing. And you have like the very lowest mitotic rate. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So your gist basically it’s it’s a really dumb one; it doesn’t really know how to metastasize. So when you’ve got a cancer, you’d rather have a dumb one than a smart one. You had a really dumb gist tumor. But you’ve kind of got a smarter prostate cancer. So the gist tumor I think is extremely unlikely… Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: …to spread to a lymphnode although it is theoretically possible. But what is far more likely given the fact that you have a prostate cancer with you know high Gleason score and a PSA that is rising… Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: …is that this is all related to the prostate cancer. So um I don’t think there’s any reason for me to believe or doubt that this is gonna be the prostate cancer. It’s theoretically possible it could be a gist. All right. I think it’s extremely, extremely unlikely. Patient: And how would we know? I knew your recommendation was that since it’s a low level in in the lymph node… Doctor: Yeah. Patient: - um that it’s something you wouldn’t biopsy, but um I guess - Doctor: The best way to find out in my opinion – Patient: Um, hum.

text: Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: On the one hand, the PSA would lead me to believe that it wasn’t, but the scans would lead me to believe, that at the very least, we achieved the stability. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So, but I, I agree with you that, that usually, although not always, usually the PSA that is rising means that the cancer is growing overall. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So that’s something to keep in mind. That’s why I’m not placing like all the emphasis on the PSA, but I’m certainly placing some emphasis on it, uh. Family Member: And so as a layperson, that’s all we have. You know? Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: That’s, that’s the only way when he gets his blood test and it comes back and, you know, you said, oh, gosh, the PSA has risen again. You know? That’s our only frame of reference as to where we are in all this and what the cancer is doing. Doctor: There’s no question that we would have preferred it would have dropped. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: But the absence of a drop does not necessarily mean the drug hasn’t worked. It, it might mean that the drug has not worked as well as we had hoped or anticipated, uh, but it might still be doing something, or it might take longer to work. To start working the drug may have to build up in your system. Patient: Um hum.

text: Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: So this is quite a paradoxical approach. Patient: Okay, good. Doctor: And it turns out that you’re absolutely right. We’ve known for a long time for about seventy years that testosterone can feed into your prostate cancer. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: However, we have recently discovered in the last three or four years that they can take a patient who has had low testosterone levels for a very long time they call that hormone-resistant prostate cancer or castration-resistant prostate cancer is another term Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Um many patients don’t like that term. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Um so that’s just hormone resistant. Patient: Okay. Doctor: In that context only, if you give back super-high doses of testosterone to the patient, and the way that we do that is we give an intra-muscular injection. It’s an injection of testosterone into the muscle that is either thigh muscle or the butt muscle. Patient: Uh huh.

text: Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: The other things we’re looking at is keeping the male castrated so all the prostate genes are turned off, and then after the new bone marrow gets all happy, you get a couple of pulse of testosterone, not to treat the cancer but to turn on the genes. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: To get the immune system. This new immune system, saying what the hell is that? It’s almost like an infection. So we’re in the early stages. We’ve treated two men. I can’t say much other than you know they did pretty well with the transplant part. Uh we’re following them. It’s really designed, my idea is for younger men, you know, less than seventy, and that is younger for me, uh, where, you know, unfortunately, you know prostate cancer grows slowly in most men. You’re probably going to live long enough that this is you know could be really- Patient: Yeah. Doctor: So, we’re, we’re uh cautiously optimistic. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: We’re also starting a study probably not for a few months yet though. We’ve had two patients now who got testosterone. They both responded to testosterone but we then put them on something for the immune therapies, just not a trial, just hit or miss. And both of those two patients had incredible response to immune therapy. Patient: Hum. Doctor: So they started like negative something, so we’re going to try a trial where we are going to prime the cancer. Not actually treat it just to get the cancer you know. So that’s- Patient: so it would somebody who just had the- Doctor: The trial is to get testosterone for three doses and then get immune therapy. Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
